reviews.review_text: I LOVED it! Brian puts the reader into his world, where you feel you are a resident of the apartment complex. You are filled with questions throughout and a sadness that Brian is gone and can no longer answer any of your questions. I am thankful I read this on my Kindle, so I can look up the vocabulary Brian uses...words I've never come  across or did not know their meaning. He will be missed.

I really, really liked Chicago by Brian Doyle.  I am familiar with Chicago, so it made the book come alive.  Doyle is an amazing writer.  He is very detail oriented, so at the end of the description you know exactly what he is talking about - it is like you are there.  I kept forgetting that Edward is a dog as he writes as if he is a person.  My first introduction to B Doyle was Mink River - another amazing book.  Thanks again to my wonderful cousin for introducing me to Doyle.I highly recommend Chicago to readers who like:  very descriptive writing, well written and well researched stories, Chicago, great fiction, and amazing use of words.

I was enthralled while reading this book and keep it by my bed so I can re-read portions of it for inspiration. Brian Doyle created a fictional world where miraculous and ordinary things are coexist seamlessly, and he nails the goodness that is at the core of Chicagoans. It's the first work of Brain Doyle's I've run across and has so much heart. I lived in Chicago as a very young child and again as a young adult, and it was a wonder for me to read a novel that recaptures so much of the inner life of the city as it was in the 1970s.

Wonderfully evocative novel about Chicago. Plot-wise it's just an account of five years living here, but in terms of nuance, fabulous vignettes and the overall feel of this book, it is a must for every Chicagoan, former Chicagoan and would-be Chicagoan. I loved it.
thought it was a fun and quirky read

summary:
On the last day of summer, a young college grad moves to Chicago and rents a small apartment on the north side of the city, by the lake. This is the story of the five seasons he lives there, during which he meets gangsters, gamblers, policemen, a brave and garrulous bus driver, a cricket player, a librettist, his first girlfriend, a shy apartment manager, and many other riveting souls, not to mention a wise and personable dog of indeterminate breed.

A love letter to Chicago, the Great American City, and a wry account of a young man’s coming-of-age during the one summer in White Sox history when they had the best outfield in baseball, Chicago is a novel that will plunge you into a city you will never forget and may well wish to visit for the rest of your days.

“This coming-of-­age novel follows a young grad student who moves to the city and meets a wide cast of colorful characters during his five-­season stay. Described as ‘a love letter to Chicago,’ Doyle's novel takes us back to a Chicago of years ago that feels both foreign and familiar.” Chicago Tribune
